Demand curves and demand elasticity

Study the following linear demand curve and decide whether it is relatively elastic, relatively inelastic, unitary elastic, or all of them:

Take note of the following:

Price elasticity of demand gives us a measure of the response of the quantity demanded to a change in the price. It is therefore closely related to (but not the same as) the slope of the demand curve. The slope of the demand curve is calculated from absolute changes in quantity and price, while price elasticity is calculated from relative changes.

As a rule of thumb, we can state that if we use the same scale on the axis, the flatter the curve that passes through a given point, the greater the price elasticity of demand will be, and the steeper the curve that passes through a given point, the smaller the price elasticity of demand will be.

Graphically, we can illustrate the different price elasticities as follows:

Inelastic demand: % change in price > % change in quantity demanded and ep <= 1

Inelastic demand

Examples are: salt, coffee, medical care and beer

A 10,5% increase in price reduces the quantity demanded by 5,1%. The lower the price elasticity of demand, the steeper the demand curve will be.

Elastic demand: % change in price < % change in quantity and ep < 1

Elastic demand

Examples are: private education, beef and fresh tomatoes.

A 10,5% increase in price decreases the quantity demanded by 29%. The higher the price elasticity of demand, the flatter the demand curve will be.

Unitary elastic demand: % change in price = % change in quantity demanded and ep = 1

Unitary elastic demand

A 10,5% increase in price decreases the quantity demanded by10,5%.

Perfectly inelastic demand curve: % change in quantity demanded = 0 and ep = 0

Perfectly inelastic demand

A 10,5% increase in price does not have an impact on the quantity demanded.

Perfectly elastic demand: % change in price causes quantity demanded to approach infinity and ep = infinity

Perfectly elastic demand
